title: Hawaiian State Representative Chris Lee announces action to combat predatory practices in gaming

embed.description: Earlier today Hawaii's State Representative Chris Lee held a press conference in response to the controversy surrounding loot boxes and microtransactions in video games. Lee announced that he would be looking to introduce legislation to combat predatory practices by companies like EA.

body:
There really is a global groundswell against predatory pricing strategies. 

It is a real shame riot have sought to roll this out.

replies.body:
The "Predatory" practices he mentions is mainly pay to win games wherein you've already purchased the full game, as well as any games that give off a false representation of loot boxes and your chances of obtaining loot. So, How does this effect League of Legends?


Odds are this exact act won't, however we're just beginning to explore this new gaming monetization practice on a political and governmental level. The next few years will be rife with more political figures and business representatives giving their two cents, all of which will go into shaping any form of governing body that may gain rights to police such practices.

The "Predatory" practices don't currently exist in League of Legends. Free rotations, champion renting through shards, free hextech chests /  keys, rewards for levelling up, there's a LOT of ways you can unlock things that are "Pay to win" ( namely Champions ). Everything else is purely cosmetic and to enhance the game for those that are willing to grind a LOT ( free chests and keys to get skins ) or spend some money for their vanity purchases.

However, there's no telling how the bodies that shall be will judge the act of loot boxes existing in general, as they ( in the eyes of many ) constitute gambling, and rely on a lot of the same principles behind how slot machines keep interest of their users psychologically.


Curious to see where this goes.

For me the loot boxes themselves are predatory because the content you desire is locked in a box with a "chance" to get it but the grind required preys on compulsive / addictive spending behavior.  There is no casual purchase of loot boxes, if you want anything halfway decent you will spend a lot before you get it. Eg it is more profitable to hide hextech annie behind lootboxes than it would be to sell it as a legendary, even though you'd spend more to get it. The capex of a $20 skin is out of reach but spending  $50 in small chunks to get the same item from loot boxes is more palatable to a teenager and is preying on that fact.

And regardless of whether you Personally think it's Predatory or not, there is going to be someone that this system is made to exploit, and that's not ok.

Any law that will be enacted is going to effect ALL lootboxes that you can spend currency to buy, so even hextech chests will be effected, because let's face it, a developer doesn't put something into the game like Hextech chests, for you not to buy them.

**Affect** Verb, **Effect** Noun. Most of the time, you'll want **affect **as a verb meaning to influence something and **effect **for the something that was influenced

not really predatory but it is still gambling. you do have a choice and it wont affect the actual gameplay due to being purely cosmetic.

I won't fight that it's pretty much gambling, but there's a minor detail that companies use to get away with such things and even target them at children.

In loot boxes, you are guaranteed to get something. Even if it's not what you wanted, you do get some sort of prize.

"Gambling" implies the risk of losing your money for nothing, whereas in loot boxes, you never just get nothing. You might get a skin shard for a champion you own, or some useless blue essence, but this minor prize in a way circumvents the definition of "Gambling."

It's the same with other things, such as the lucky dip boxes you see at childrens stores, and Trading card booster packs for ( Name a TCG with rares, shinies ect. ) and because you get something every time, they are technically classified as "games of chance" and not directly gambling.

Changes SHOULD be made, and it is pretty much gambling. Here's to knowing the info.

They have been an INCREDIBLY profitable company for years without lootboxes so dont give me that giving away millions nonsense. And like any dealer they give a little taste first to get you hooked then empty your pockets when you are addicted.

Lootbox giveaways were a strategic decision not a clumsy mistake. They lost nothing - they were investing time in trialling the system and getting everyone comfortable with the interface before monetising it. These are strategic moves years in the making. Merrill isn't worth 2.3billion for nothing.

Wake up for fucks sake and stop defending this dick move designed with the sole purpose of squeezing players more for raw profit in an already incredibly profitable game.

I'm just saying, as someone who has never bought loot boxes in my life the vast majority of my skin collection is what I've gotten for free. Before the free loot boxes there was no way to get skins without paying, with one or two rare exceptions. It has been a big advantage for those of us that gauge our spending towards this game with care, or don't spend at all. If people feel like they are being squeezed to buy them then I pity those people for their astoundingly weak fortitude. As you say, any dealer does this sort of thing. We live with a capitalistic economy where everyone prices and markets their product to take advantage of the buyer. So, if a buyer is bumbling about throwing their money at everything that sparkles in their eye they are a fool.
they could still give lootboxes out for free as a reward. it's selling them in unlimited quantitites that is the problem.

See for me buying skins is no big deal. I actively bought them because i was happy to support the game. But the lootbox model is one that preys on a thirst for content, and rather than a clear cut transaction where i buy a for b, i have to buy c for b to get a chance at a.

Honestly purchasing skins was ftp done right - whenever I hear people say "be nice to riot it's a free game" i laugh because over the years i have spent more on this game (somewhere between $600-$900, depending on whether my wife is in earshot) than any other because i agreed with the business model and enjoyed the game and was more than happy to support it.

But the lootbox model is abhorrent - it is a virtual lottery which muddies the transaction and preys on compulsive behaviours to extract more cash for the same product.  I bought a couple when they first came out and quickly realised that getting hextech annie would likely cost me more than buying 3 or 4 legendarys outright. It is a system designed to harvest money and nothing else.

Just to be perfectly clear, Spending cash on lol has never ever been an issue for me. Its been about $75-$150 per year for me since about season 2 because i agreed with the model, enjoyed the game, and was more than happy to support it. but predatory pricing in games is what is killing modern gaming. Ea are americas most hated for a reason and i am sad to see riot go down the same path and angry that such a profitable company is moving towards exploitative pricing when all around the world the practice is under significant scrutiny because it exploits the vulnerable,  and in this case vulnerable teenagers.

Apologies for my colourful language - i am pretty passionate about this. By moving in this direction riot have gone from being the undefeated heroes of modern ftp done absolutely right to the villains ripping money out of the pockets of teenagers.
It's amazing, but this game was Free To Play before they added lootboxes.
